Ring Shout by P. Djèlí Clark is the perfect fantasical horror story to pull you away from the real life one we’ve been living this week.

Set almost a hundred years ago in Macon, Georgia, Ring Shout follows Maryse Boudreaux, a monster slayer who is hunting the KKK. Not just Klan members, though, but a particularly heinous type of demon that walks around in human skin. They’re called Ku Kluxes, and they have infiltrated one of the most hateful organizations in the last 100 years of American histor

absolutely phenomenal.

i have no words, except that i feel similarly to how i felt after watching Get Out for the first time: utterly blown away. filled with vindictive, fury-driven satisfaction. kind of shocked to find myself somehow back in my own reality (though i must admit, the line between fantasy/reality in both of these stories is a FINE one indeed). and ready for a re-read/watch already.

jordan peele needs to turn this into a movie STAT

From the start, P. Djeli Clark's RING SHOUT explodes into vivid color with a voice that's at once joyous and harrowing. Maryse is a stunning character, real and layered, and brilliantly employed in a novella that is confident, razor sharp, and utterly imaginative. An instant favorite.

Ring Shout is a weird and smart little novella that blurs the lines between historical fantasy and horror. It follows a group of Black women in the 1920's who hunt evil KKK members, but with a twist. This is a fascinating story that serves to frame very real history through a fantastical lens that perhaps allows for a different approach to insight. It has impressively deep worldbuilding and well-developed characters despite the length.

The cover and synopsis of Ring Shout drew me to this book. This historical science fiction novella is about three Black women from 1920s Georgia (Maryse, Sadie, and Chef) who are bootleggers and hunters of monsters known as Ku Kluxes. Ku Kluxes are people who turned into monsters when hate infected their bodies. This book is a good social commentary on the effect that hate has on the perpetrators and theirs victims. Above all, Ring Shout is a book about hate.
Set in 1920s Georgia, this long novella mingles historical facts with African American folktales to create a vibrant, deliciously creepy setting that is guaranteed to haunt your dreams.

The research behind it is meticulous - the author is a professor of history specializing in the trans-Atlantic slave trade - and, as any serious reader can tell you, just because something is fiction doesn't mean it's not *true*.

I would have liked a better explanation of the universe and a more complete plot, but overall it's an interesting read. I didn't connect much with the characters.

Much of the story focuses on the rerelease of The Birth of a Nation, a real film that is derogatory towards African Americans. Maryse was warned that the rerelease would cause a huge surge of hatred towards African Americans, and so has to fight to stop this.

Ring Shout is a historical set horror novel about Black Americans hunting down monsters that spur on the hatred of White supremacists in the South.

I have had P. Djeli Clark on my radar for a while now, with him releasing various novellas through Tor.com. After reading the premise of this one, I had to give it a whirl. He knocked it out of the park.

The world Clark creates is set in the early 1900's following World War 1 set in Georgia, following a cast of black females who are hunting Kluxes, demonic monsters inhabiting members of the KKK. Insanely cool concept right? And boy does Clark deliver.

This is so well researched and thought out

Thanks to NetGalley for this audiobook. The narrator of this dark fantasy was incredible. The story is character driven and I loved Maryse and her magic sword. Sadie was an extremely likeable character.

This is a story about monsters. Otherworldly beings and those who walk amongst us. The Klu Kluxes are pure hatred and evil personified as shape shifting monsters - and only a small band of female warriors can see them for what they really are.

This is a tale of vengeance and injustice, gore and terror and ultimately love and hope. I loved reading about Maryse and her band of strong women, and really enjoyed how African myth and history was incorporated into this story. It was a great adventure.

Well, there's a magic sword, too. And plenty of awesome cosmic horror, as well some dashes of light fantasy. Oh, and these awesome ladies are also bootleggers, for some added swoon! RING SHOUT by P. Djèlí Clark is one of the best books of 2020. It is so unique and downright spectacular. Tor continues to impress me with their novellas.

The story takes place in Macon, Georgia, during the 1920s Prohibition. G.W. Griffith releases a film called Birth of a Nation, and when Ku Klux Klan members view it, they become evil demons called Ku Kluxes. Our main protagonist, twenty-five-year-old Maryse Boudreaux, is aware of this and takes action along with help from her allies, the resist

Overall, this is without a doubt one of my favorite books of 2020. I think my new favorite sub-genre is the specific "Lovecraftian horror, but intentionally and completely rejects/subverts the racist overtones of Lovecraft's writing by using the inter-dimensional monsters as a tool to write a story about fighting for justice and equity" (Also in this vein would be The City We Became by N. K. Jemisin)

As for the story, what's relevant in the US in 1922 is still relevant 98 years later. Clark perfe

From Dead Djinn, to Tram Car 015, and now Ring Shout, Clark manages to make his worlds as familiar as they are rich and vividly imaginative. His settings become places I've been before. His characters are people I know. His magic is something I've witnessed or wielded in tangible memories. RING SHOUT is no different. Here, he's found the only way to write about the Klan that doesn't give me violent, ancestral fits. A feat, all things considered.

"It takes two heartbeats for them fix on me. Then they’re galloping on all fours, snarling and marking me as prey. But like I said already, I hunt monsters. And I got a sword that sings."

Djèlí Clark makes that monstrosity literal in a fantastical setting of a post-world-war Southern United States, where senseless hate invokes the attention of the purest evil, and connections to ancestral roots manifest in magic and spiritual power.

As the book begins, it’s only about a year out from the Tulsa Massacre, which you may have seen depicted on Watchmen. If you didn’t, then the briefest explanation is that a group flattened Tulsa’s prosperous Black community basically because they could.

I could be fanciful and call them a group of monsters or something like that.

Cardiff by the Sea by Joyce Carol Oates

These four unrelated novellas carry similar themes. Female protagonists of varying ages are all highly intimidated by male figures. At some point, they all gain a degree of strength and growth.

Knives, suicide, death, hiding or running away, physically or figuratively, play a role in each story. All leading characters are tiny in size or make themselves small to not be seen. There is an element of magical realism or escapism as well.

This is a book about being lost, life and death, and redemption. In Irish folklore, there is a fourth Aran island, Inis Caillte, off the coast of Ireland. It is where people who are lost and despairing go when they die. Once there, they are immediately accepted by the other residents because everyone is lost and there are no language barriers.

The Fourth Island by Sarah Tolmie is the haunting story set in a village in the Aran Islands. When a body washes ashore it sets in motion a mystery the inhabitants try desperately to solve. What surfaces is a fourth Island off the coast of Ireland where only those who dwell in despair can make it there through their own darkest moments.

From the beginning, this novel sets an ominous atmosphere with its

An interesting work of speculative fiction infused with Irish folklore. The eponymous "Fourth Island" refers to Inis Caillte, a hidden island that calls to the lost, saving them from death, isolation, and despair. The island erases all barriers of language, difference, and even time, creating a secret community that transforms its unwitting inhabitants into a softer, truer version of themselves.

[3/5: Atmospheric and almost philosophical. You can almost feel the sea mist on your face through the
Library Journal Express reviews recommends it for fans of The Bird King and This Is How You Lose the Time War.

The Fourth Island is not the kind of book where there is a set character focus or story being told. It winds in and out of various lives to tell the tale of the island as a whole, and how it relates to the inhabitants and their connections off the island. Tolmie does an excellent job of creating a lively narrative that gracefully flows from point to point. I love the concept, but I will be the first to admit that I struggle with works that do not feel like they have a beginning, middle, and end.

I love the language and the atmosphere of this story, and I love how succinctly Tolmie writes. She uses few words, but evokes everything she wants you to experience with those few words. She's a poet, though, so she's probably used to performing this trick.

Struggled with how to rate this. Three stars for the writing, which was fine from a technical point of view, but if I were rating by story it would be two stars.

Wow, that was depressing! This novella ranks with Ormeshadow in terms of cramming the most possible gloominess into relatively few pages.

I expected a fourth Aran island to be mysterious and mythical and magical, but it only seems to collect random people for no apparent reason and to export gloom and despair to the other islands.

This novella isn't really a story. Instead it's a series of vignettes tied together by the general theme of the magical fourth Aran island Inis Caillte. So if you are expecting a story with a beginning, a middle and an end, then you need to look elsewhere.

If you are willing to accept the novella for what it is then you'll find it a series of charming observations about people and the lives they lead. There is nothing of great consequence here, but it's a pleasant way to spend an hour.

An invisible island for lost souls to receive a second chance at living; it's an interesting, if haunting, concept. I do like how the author describes despair as a disease, and how it can spread from person to person and wreck havoc upon a community - especially one so small and close-knit - if not checked.

The only thing is the prose was a little hard to get through at parts, when the language started getting convoluted and too metaphorical, and I had to double-back to reread.

There are three known Aran islands off of Ireland. Sarah Tolmie’s tale of The Fourth Island (paper from Tor) where only people who truly despair live, starts with a dead body washing ashore on Inis Môr with a sweater with an unrecognizable pattern. Can he learn to deal with the fear of losing Sarah long enough to realize his love for her?

It looks like there’s a lot of tie ins with the major cosmere universe that I’ll have to research. There’s a fun story here and some good characters. It’s nowhere near as epic as the main books in the series, but it’s not trying to be and I think it pulls off what it was going for without

Dawnshard is what you expect/want a novella set in-between two epic (!) Stormlight Archive novels to be: easy, enjoyable, entertaining. So if you’re a fan of the series, you should definitely spend a leisurely afternoon getting to know Rysn, Lopen, Huio and Rock’s daughter Cord better. (In all fairness, Lopen is nowhere near my my favorite bridgemen but you can expect some character growth from him towards the end.)

I'm curious to find out to what extent this novella is relevant to Rhythm of War

Whereas Edgedancer felt like a true novella, like it stood by itself, Dawnshard feels like a few chapters taken from the next giant Stormlight book. Its tendrils extend deep into the events and characters of other books, and you've got to dig back into the deep lore of Stormlight to "get" this book.

It's a fun seafaring adventure, but I still don't really know what a Dawnshard is?!

Wow. For what is essentially a side piece to the main Stormlight series, I was shocked at how pertinent this story was. Not just to the Stormlight Archive, but the Cosmere and its fate as a whole.

Novellas like these just show that one should pay very close attention to the Interludes in the main books, as they are littered with Easter eggs and clues for future projects. It's made we want to go back and read Edgedancer, as I don't think I appreciated the gravity of that at the time.

Alas, that w

4.5 stars. It's a little slow in the first half, and I'm not sure that the second half would make up for it on its own. However, for the Cosmere aware reader, the secrets revealed are amazing and astounding. No spoilers, but let's just say that the dawnshards are not what I thought they were.

I loved Rysn's heroics at the climax, and we see more depth and growth of character from the Lopen than anything we've seen from the other Stormlight books. This is a solid and important addition the Stormli

Absolutely amazing. Much like Edgedancer, it was great to see some of the stranger parts of Roshar get fleshed out, and Rysn has grown so much as a character. Giving her her own novella was a perfect capstone to her arc and I can't wait to see what comes next.

High seas and exploration books are always fun in general and this one really knocks it out of the park. Strong Voyage of the Dawn Treader vibes going on, in the best way.

A fun read that focuses on the interesting side characters of Rysn and The Lopen. I appreciate Brandon's diligence to get the details of Rysn's handicap accurate. The Lopen's journey of self-discovery through his conversations with Huio were meaningful but of course still had humor, and I love seeing different character's unique Ideals. Big cosmere drops: the Sleepless are not native to Roshar, Dawnshards are Commands (not items) that created Aldonalsium but also shattered him, there are four Da

This is a Stormlight novella (a long novella) that was made available last week as part of the recent Kickstarter that Brandon did for the leather bound edition of The Way of Kings. It's self-contained, but you really benefit from knowing the backstory of several of the characters. It was also a very enjoyable way of bringing the whole Stormlight universe back into my fore-brain after three years, ready for Rhythm of War which is coming out in about ten days time.

Besides being one of the shortest books ever (thanks, Brandon Sanderson, for thinking a novel-length book is “short”), Dawnshard was a lot of fun.

Getting the perspectives of The Lopen and Rysn was entertaining to say the least, and there were some powerful messages in the story as well. Exciting action and some juicy cosmere tidbits to boot. Let’s just say that, as I anticipate the release of Rhythm of War, Dawnshard was far too short.

This is certainly a far shorter novel (technically a novella) than Brandon's normal fare and it certainly was a much smaller affair though still packed with a lot of juicy details. Frankly, I'm surprised there was as much relevant information for the Cosmere here. I loved reading Rysh, Lopen and Cord. I wish there was an infinite pages to follow side chracters go on their own journey and path. Now I can't wait for the 4th stormlight book. Here we go!

4.5 / 5

Well that certainly was A LOT of informations.

I just read it in one sitting (always nice to be able to do that with a Sanderson story). I really enjoyed the two POV of Rysn and Lopen. It was a lot of fun (especially with Lopen's chapters) and now I'll go read stuff on reddit and on the coppermind wiki because I'm sure I've missed a lot of informations..!

Oh also , Sanderson does horror now? I wasnt ready for this 😂

This is probably my new favourite of Sanderson's companion short stories - probably because it didn't feel so much like a random "side quest", but far more integral to the overall story. Several characters we have met before, and it was nice to get to know them better. The pacing was good (which is often a problem I have with his work), and the plot was good. Not a super exciting installment, but I did enjoy it.

Okay, so, *that* happened.

Wow.

I was expecting a fill-in-the-gaps-btween-novels piece, similar to Edgedancer.

I was not expecting....well....that.

Which is to say, Dawnshard is one of the most important installments in the Cosmere.

And I am very excited to see that one of my favorite characters, who thusfar has had a very minor role in the Stormlight series, may soon become one of the most important figures in Sanderson's mythos.

Rysn is one of my favorite side characters and I was so unbelievably happy to read her novella!! She's so great. I enjoyed the story as well and as per usual Brandon Sanderson fashion, I have a ton more questions!!!

My only complaint is Lopen. I really can't stand his character mostly. I don't understand why anyone thinks he's funny or a fun character, he's just so annoying. However, it seems at the end there may be some changes in his character so we'll hopefully see if he gets tolerable.

Truth be told, I don't expect to like Rhythm of War as much as I liked this tightly written, just plain fun, novella. Turns out when restricted to a shorter format and to exploring the corners, edges and side-characters of Roshar, I find myself entertained and compelled just as much, if not more than in the (much, much) longer novels. It helps that Rysn has always been a highlight of the main novels' interludes, and now finds herself undeniably among the best characters of the series.

Overall, I loved this book. Mostly on the lighter side, which is what I'm looking for these days. Lopen and Rysn were great as main POV characters, as were some of the side characters. The tidbits for overall Cosmere was unexpected.

If I had to nitpick, there were plenty of things happening that it would've needed a much longer book to give them justice, especially the decisions made in the climax.

It is a novella. Never expect too much from a Novella, but it was still a good one.

I really missed this world, and even if The Lopen was the only character that featured in the main parts of the previous books, he was still awesome as always.

And Sanderson putting so much character development into Rysn in some 100 pages shows how great of a storyteller he is.

Also the ending leaves us with more questions than answers as always. Can’t wait for RoW release next week. HYPE!

I loved this book. Heartfelt, positive story. I’m a sucker for stories that explore new places, creating something new, and making even small, side characters awesome. Rysn shines all over in the book. The amount of work Brandon has done for Rhysn is to be appreciated.

This book has significant Cosmere mysteries. I really liked how he gives just enough information to make fans hungry for more.

I have already finished part 1 of ROW. Need to wait only 2 more days. Yippee.

Definitely enjoyed this addition! I was so glad to see some characters appear and glad to delve into a side character more. I love the perspective of the main character, a unique one you don't see often in literature. This novella also makes the mysteries of Roshar and the Cosmere all the more intriguing.

I did feel that some of the plot was too convenient and a solution to a previous problem too easily solved, pushing believability, thus the four stars.

Fantastic, an easy 5! Some of my favorite side-characters teaming up to go to my favorite side-location to reveal some majorly central new lore. This is basically the perfect book for me. Hard to explain exactly what I mean without going into specifics but this short novel not only majorly advances characters I DO like, it was a huge step forward for one character I have so far really been disliking.

Without spoiling anything this is absolutely required reading for Stormlight and Cosmere fans.

I LOVED THIS SO FREAKING MUCH!!!!

This was seriously SO much better than I was expecting???? I mean, I shouldn’t doubt a Sanderson book... but novellas are normally boring guys- filler books. THIS THOUGH!? That was the most fun and depressingly gross book I’ve read in Fantasy!!

(I think I need more books written on ships)

I’m gonna read Edgedancer next (I skipped it cause I don’t like novellas- don’t come at me) because I loved this so much, I’m sure I’ll love it too!!

Truly, truly exception. Every sentence is filled with purpose, and every event is rich with lore. With that said, we have soundly left the Sanderson era where you can pick up and read more or less anywhere. I've heard this book advertised as a possible standalone and it most certainly is not. I would say this novella requires not just knowledge of the previous Stormlight books, but as many others as you can get read.

I read this book in two sittings and the only reason it took two is that I started reading it too late in the evening and literally could not stay awake long enough to finish it.

It's a lovely novella that adds interesting pieces to the Cosmere-puzzle (at least for me who haven't read so many Cosmere books yet), and lets you get closer to characters you haven't gotten the chance to spend so much time with.

Authors and narrator always bring the listener along for a fabulous story every time.

I know it's after Christmas but I needed a listen for today and I wanted to get all the bubbles of joy in one hit. It was short, sweet and gave me one of the biggest and goofiest grins at the end that I HAD to give it 5 stars.

I listened to this quick Audible original while I did some weekend cleaning - it's a contemporary romance with two narrators. It all starts when an advice columnist receives a question from one person at a company and accidentally replies to the other.

In poking around I discovered that what the male narrator looks like is a big mystery - his voice is awfully familiar to me and I have some guesses....

Riley Kennedy and Kennedy Riley work for the same company and occasionally get each other's mail. Then Kennedy actually comments on one of Riley's emails and Riley writes a scathing response. She never expects to actually meet the man, but when they do, sparks fly and they end up being each others fake dates for upcoming events.

This is a quick and fun audio short that pings off a couple of common romance tropes (fake dating, enemies to lovers).

I was actually quite charmed by this one! I liked the little hook of people with unisex names that can also be last names as the way that the main characters encounter each other, and I think this book overall managed to deliver on the well worn trope elements that we love (fake relationships, home for Christmas, etc.) but with plenty of little twists and lovely character moments. I've not read anything from these authors, but this makes me want to read more!

user_name: Lindsey Domokur of Crazy Reader Chicks
review_text: This novella was adorable. It reminded me a lot of one of my favorite books, The Hating Game, but there were also differences intertwined. I loved Riley and Kennedy so much. Each of them had pretty significant baggage coming into this "deal". Riley was looking for love and Kennedy wasn't sure what he was looking for but commitment wasn't on his radar. I feel like the first time he bantered with Riley he knew she would be more to him. It was so cute.

It's what you expect from a short, cute holiday romance. I didn't care for how the narration was done - female and male narrators switching after each chapter and each reading both the female and male dialogues for their chapters. It should have been one primary narrator and the female speaking the female dialogue and the male speaking the male dialogue.

This was a cute(ish) seasonal read. I wasn't a huge fan of the MCs, especially Kennedy and his stalkerish behavior.

Also, it felt like this had so much packed into such a shorter story. With all the drama, I couldn't focus on one thing before the next item was introduced.

If you like hate to love and fake dating, this may be for you though!

You can take the agent out of the FBI but, you can't take the FBI out of the agent.

Cate has tried valiantly to separate her past life as an FBI agent as she settles down on Widow's Island and run a bakery and book store. Then a local out with his dog discovers a human bone and as the investigation is launched, Cate tries to resist a request to share her expertise and reluctantly jumps in with both feet.

With this one Cate finally has to face her past and her present. Things happen where an old case has connections to the present and Cate is pulled in to help figure things out. In the course of the investigation Cate has to face what made her walk away to begin with and to finally decide what the FBI holds for her. I think she made the right decision. As to the crime and the bad guy, it's a sad story all around.

Originally written in Japanese, Convenience Store Woman on the surface is a story about Keiko Furukura, a woman whose own parents labeled "a strange child." Slow to develop, Keiko's parents were worried about her ability to "fit in" and be a "normal" adult. They wish for Keiko to have a "real job" and a boyfriend. As an adult she finds the perfect job, because it comes with a manual that spells out how to act and dress in every situation. A quick read with an interesting character.

In The Heart of the Fire is book one of the Nameless series by Dean Koontz. A collection of short stories.

This book introduces you to the character, Nameless, who suffers from amnesia and doesn’t know his real name or anything about his past. He is hired by an agency to carry out missions to eliminate bad people. Nameless also has moments of clairvoyance seeing snippets from the past and the future. He can see what his actions may or may not do.

In this book, Nameless eliminates a child predator.

This is brilliant. The Man With No Name (Clint Eastwood) meets Jack Reacher with some Person of Interest thrown in. Short stories about a nameless vigilante, helped/controlled by a shadowy group, who has no memory of a time before he was 'activated'. He lives to bring justice to the truly evil. These are fast paced, relentless, no deviation from the objective short stories, and I love them. They are dangerously addictive. I'm on book 3 already.

I loved that I really felt like I knew them and their shared history. I loved the storyline and as always the writing is exceptional. This is the book that I needed this week.

Kandi does it again!

She can create small town magic and everything about it is perfect!

Kandi makes you want to find the love that Eliza and River have.

Distance only makes the love grown fonder and that’s exactly this book! You want to devour this one in a day! I could hardly put it down!

Eliza and River are the perfect example of love never fading!

Thank you Kandi for this opportunity as always!

In true Kandi Steiner fashion, I cried and heart heart felt all the feels with this sweet Christmas novella. I just loved River and Eliza. I am sure my husband thought I was insane as I wrapped my arms around him and told him how much I love him when I finished this story. But Kandi Steiner does that to me every time. I get sucked into the emotions and cry my eyes out. I highly recommend this one. Its perfect for the holiday season!

It's so amazing how some authors can pack a giant punch in such a short novella and have you devouring each word as of it might just be the last ones you ever lays eyes upon.

I was so drawn to both Eliza and River and just wanted them to finally get their HEA. Yes they did of course but I'm hoping Ms. Steiner will give us more of them and they're adventures after they found their way back to each other again. 

Perfect story to put you in the holiday spirit!

But when she comes back, who does she encounter but her ex-husband. Being trapped together brings up the past, the memories good and bad, and figuring out what they needed then and what they need now.

A sweet, feel-good story with a batch of emotions you won't want to miss out on.

A sweet Christmas read!!!

The chapter animations and colors are beautiful and just right for the holiday season. Loved it!

THIS WAS EVERYTHING!!! Kandi left me wanting more from this couple!!

Eliza is back in town and not expecting to run into who is now her ex husband. Without giving much away, Eliza needed to find herself in order to know where her heart belonged. It was exactly what I needed. Now... thinking it’s time to check out those Becker brothers!

The Christmas Blanket by the wonderful romance author Kandi Steiner has some deep moments that made Eliza reconsider what she had and realize what her ex, River, had been through during the years she was gone. This second chance holiday novella was angsty and heartbreaking, but also full of holiday magic and remembrance…brought on by chance and the holiday spirit. This was an enjoyable, quick read with a great deep-feeling storyline.

It was sweet and short. Well written and perfect if you’re looking for a palette cleanser, also if you’re into hallmark Christmas movies.

I was expecting more, maybe a little bit of angst, a lot more of groveling and I don’t know, just more.
The whole story develops practically inside one cabin and then it’s over.

This is what happens when you have high expectations. Don’t let this review deter you from reading, it is sweet.

What a journey!

What a super sweet holiday romance! The Christmas Blanket is this incredibly wonderful holiday second chance romance. It’s a novella so it isn’t long but boy, does it pack a punch to your heart....angsty & deeply emotional. I adored it and my only complaint is that I wanted more. I wanted to see the journey that Eliza and River went on so much but my heart was still happy knowing they were going on that journey. I would highly recommend.

I read this book in just a few hours. Kandi is one of my one click authors and I’ll purchase a book of hers no questions asked. This book was very sweet with the intimate scenes bringing the heat. There were moments when they were finding themselves again that gave me chills and gripped my stomach. It ended exactly like I thought but I absolutely adored. As soon as it was over, I wanted to start it again. Solid 5 stars again from Kandi.

Happy almost holiday season. This was lit.

Second book in the series. Nameless a guy with no name or past that he can remember. Deals out justice to evil wrong doers. During clairvoyant moments he sees episodes of past and present crimes. He works for a team off unknown people. He doesn't know how he came to be in this situation. Total amnesia has a grip of his past. But he knows he is dealing justice and ridding the world of evil.

Getting to know the main character better

The second installation following the character "Nameless," provides more details and information regarding who Nameless may have been before who he currently is. It's a good read, and slightly longer than the first installment, but still lacking in the usually more developed books Koontz is know for writing. Definitely still worth reading, even if you haven't read the first book in the series.

The second of a series of six novellas featuring Nameless, a hunter of serial killers with no memory of his life before stepping into this role. He has multiple aliases but doesn't know his true name, and works for someone who is also unknown to him. The target in this entry is a highly unusual killer with no preferential type of victim and a seemingly unlimited amount of financial resources. The psychology of Nameless and his current target are well drawn and intriguing.

Palmer Oxenwald considers himself a avatar of death.Over the years he has taken the lives of many.Both male and female.Young and old.For him it isn't a specific type of victim that draws him but the act of snuffing out a life itself.However unbeknownst to him the hunter is being hunted.With the backing of a secret organization the man known as Nameless knows everything he needs to know about Palmer and how to stop him.As for Palmer he will learn whats it like for a predator to become prey.

Nameless continues...

Just as riveting as the first, the Nameless saga continues and now we really start to wander; Who is Nameless? Did he volunteer for this life? Who is the organization behind him? His Contact?

The nameless hero continues to do good, even as we ate left with more questions. Can the organization that created him turn on him? Is his amnesia self inflicted?

As always Koontz gets you hooked with his masterful prose. Off to book 3...

Great Read

Love the Nameless character I cant wait learn more about him and Ace Of Diamonds as weelas the elusive Salazar . Justice for innocent lives lost is very hard to get or at least it's a Gamble even if they are able.catch the guilty, Theres never a guarantee will get Justice
I think it's one the reason I love reading this series, If only people like Nameless really existed

This one was ok but it didn’t suck me in like the first in the series. It took me a while to get into. I feel like a book as short as this can’t really afford to not grab your attention right away. I was more interested in Nameless than the actual case he was on. Hopefully more about him will be revealed. Oh well. On to the third one. 2 stars.

Plotless

I am liking the series, but I feel like the plots are grossly under developed. Wish the books were longer. I want to know more about Palmer's sister Rochelle. I want to know more about Dennis. I wAnt to know more about Palmers childhood. I was left with a lot of unanswered questions.

Recommend to crime fiction readers.

In this second book of the Nameless Series by Dean Koontz, Nameless tracks a very rich serial killer, who thinks he is not crazy but rather Death incarnate. A specialist joins nameless in order assist in the meting out of an appropriate punishment for this agent of Death.

Intriguing series of books with a decent story arc.

Poignancy runs like a river throughout this novella. One cannot help become attached to the protagonist. The evil described is in the form of a character which can be found in many of Koontz novels. Makes one hunger for the next in the series.

Nameless Again Saves tbe Day

Sooooo, did you know that you can get this for $1.99 right now???

I am so down to read a story about a Black heroine kicking butt at a space academy. Like, PLEASE.

This book is about Binti, a member of the Himba people (an actual ethnic group, google it). The novella imagines a distant future in which society has changed but the Himba people are still significantly cut off from the rest of the world. Binti is named a "master harmonizer" of her town, and incredibly good at a meditation called "treeing", which involves doing exponentially complex mathematical equations in her head. These talents earn her a full scholarship to the best college in the galaxy,

Binti is a talented 17 year old girl in Namibia who sneakes off her village without the consent of her relatives to study mathematics at the prestigiuous Oomza Uni at some distant planet. She has never left her village before and her folk, the Himba, are quite isolated. Some mysterious technology at the edge between fantasy and SF comes in - she is a so called "Harmonizer", working on miraculous "Astrolabes". She is confronted with lots of prejudices against her culture, including the habit of o

I need something short and punchy after a book hangover. Tom (SFF180) suggested Binti and it was exactly what the doctor ordered.

I sometimes struggle with short form fiction because a lot of what I love in stories takes longer: flowery writing, character development, introspection, etc. That isn't to say that those things aren't possible in short fiction, but only that I've found it's difficult to achieve.

Nnedi Okorafor achieved it. She's told an engaging, rich, meaningful story with economy.

4 stars. Why was this so short? I want more! The audiobook is movie length at 2h 30m so it went by incredibly fast. This could’ve been Game of Thrones audiobook length and I would still want more.

The writing is absolutely gorgeous. It’s very scenic and draws you in. I had no problem imagining the setting. Under the right hands, this could make a fantastic film. It’s a very unique story and I loved the main character Binti. I thought she was interesting and I like the way she handled things. I ca

The cover is so beeeaaauuutiful!

The story is good, too, and well-narrated by the audiobook reader.

My one unanswered question: What did it mean that Binti made the mud (ojise?) from another planet when, even though it's considered a covering like clothing, it was a direct connection to her ancestral home? Was that foreshadowing? Or an oversight?

Best thing about this installment: LIVING SPACECRAFT!
I do not know why but I am always completely charmed with the idea of a living spacecraft.

LOVE!


SO
